item.title: Running two minecraft versions
item.dc:creator: @xryz xryz
item.description:
@xryz wrote:

i dont know batch very well (this is like my first batch file like this) but i put this together in like 3 mins so sorry if it doesnt work, plus im pressed on time. i have an assignment in class that im suppose to be doing as i type. this is just what mitb said except in a windows batch file:

[code]@echo off
color 3
title Start MineCraft
:start
echo choose which MineCraft version you want to play.
echo .
echo 1. 1.1_02
echo 2. 1.2_02
echo 3. exit
set /p choice=enter your choice 1,2,3:
if %choice%==1 goto old
if %choice%==2 goto new
if %choice%==3 exit

:old
copy %appdata%.minecraft\bin\minecraft-1.1_02.jar %appdata%.minecraft\bin\minecraft.jar
java -jar %appdata%.minecraft\minecraft_launcher.jar
exit

:new
copy %appdata%.minecraft\bin\minecraft-1.2_02.jar %appdata%.minecraft\bin\minecraft.jar
java -jar %appdata%.minecraft\minecraft_launcher.jar
exit[/code]

edit: i updated the batch script. where “%appdata%/.minecraft/” is in “%appdata%/.minecraft/minecraft_launcher.jar” u can change that. idk where ur launcher is but ik i have a launcher in the mincraft folder. if u create that batch in the same folder as the launcher you can just edit those lines to: “java -jar minecraft_launcher.jar”. and if i remember correct “/” is for unix, and “” is for windows. i think that may cause it not to work so i fixed that. lett me know how it works. i may try it later today if i have time.

Read full topic

item.title: Running two minecraft versions
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

When you open the windows command-line, you are running in a dos shell. Most unix-like operating systems, such as Linux, FreeBSD, Mac OSX, etc etc, use a bash shell (or CAN use a bash shell, but most of them do by default).

en.wikipedia.org

Bash (Unix shell)

Bash is a Unix shell and command language written by Brian Fox for the GNU Project as a free software replacement for the Bourne shell. First released in 1989, it has been distributed widely as the default login shell for most Linux distributions and Apple's macOS (formerly OS X). A version is also available for Windows 10. It is also the default user shell in Solaris 11. Bash is a command processor that typically runs in a text window, where the user types commands that cause actions. Bash can ...

You can use a bash shell and run shell scripts and such in windows too, through the use of cygwin.

Read full topic

item.title: Running two minecraft versions
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

You know the minecraft.jar you copy into your bin folder? Make a backup of both and simply rename the one you want to play to minecraft.jar (don’t rename, copy it so you don’t lose the original)

If you don’t want to do it manually, just have scripts you use to start minecraft, a bash script would look something like:

cp ~/.minecraft/bin/minecraft-1.1_02.jar ~/.minecraft/bin/minecraft.jar
java -jar /path/to/minecraft_launcher.jar

and for 1.2:

cp ~/.minecraft/bin/minecraft-1.2_02.jar ~/.minecraft/bin/minecraft.jar
java -jar /path/to/minecraft_launcher.jar

Easy isn’t it?

Read full topic
